title: 106_hr4730
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia Recognition Act". The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia are descendants and political successors to the original Creek Indian Nation at the time of European contact and signatories of the 1832 Treaty of Washington. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, descendants of the original Creek Indian Nation, declined removal under the 1832 Treaty of Washington and continue to operate as a sovereign tribe with over 2,500 eligible members residing in Georgia. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, descendants of the original Creek Indian Nation, declined removal under the 1832 Treaty of Washington. They continue to exist with a viable tribal government, petitioning for Federal recognition in 1972. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia petitioned for Federal recognition in 1972 but lacked proper legal counsel and historical information. Their petition was denied in 1981 due to technical omissions. Despite this, the Federal Government and local governments have recognized their political leaders. The political leaders of the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia have been recognized by the government as leaders of a distinct political entity. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "member" refers to an enrolled member of the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia or an individual placed on the membership rolls in accordance with this Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Tribe" refers to the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia. Federal recognition is extended to the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, making them eligible for all federal benefits and services available to recognized Indian tribes and their members. This includes laws and regulations applicable to Indians without the need for a reservation. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia is federally recognized, granting them access to federal benefits and services. The Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 applies to the Tribe and its members. SEC. 5. RESERVATION. The Tribe can transfer land to the Secretary for trust within 2 years, establishing the initial reservation land. Gaming is prohibited on the trust land. SEC. 6. BASE MEMBERSHIP ROLL. The Tribe must submit a membership roll to the Secretary within 120 days of the Act's enactment, based on the Tribe's Constitution. The Secretary will publish the roll in the Federal Register, and the Tribe is responsible for keeping it current. The Tribe has the right to determine future membership. The Tribe has the right to determine future membership, with individuals needing to be lineal descendants on the base membership roll and maintain political relations with the Tribe. The reservation established by this Act will be considered Indian country under Federal and tribal jurisdiction. This Act will not affect any treaties or rights secured to tribes mentioned in the Act.
